circle.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a completely round shape, like the letter O
circle.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Draw a circle 10 cm in diameter.
circle.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a group of people or things arranged in the shape of a circle
circle.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The children stood round in a circle.
circle.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a group of people who know each other and meet regularly, or who have similar interests or jobs
circle.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Johnson was part of the president’s inner circle (=the people who have the most influence).
circle.translation[0].definitions[3].def: the upper floor of a theatre, that has seats arranged in curved rows
circle.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 3: a group of people who know each other and meet regularly, or who have similar interests or jobs
circle.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: a circle of friends
Over the years she had established a circle of good friends.
a circle of acquaintances
She has a wide circle of acquaintances.
a circle of admirers
When she was young, Sophie had a large circle of male admirers.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + circle
academic/political/literary etc  circles
There has been a lot of debate about this issue in political circles.
a wide/large circle
They now had a wide circle of acquaintances in the area.
a small/narrow circle
Ken was the centre of a small circle of artists and writers.
somebody’s inner circle
He was among the prime minister’s inner circle of advisers.
a social circle
Dan and I didn’t mix in the same social circles.
the family circle
It’s important for children to have friends outside the family circle.
somebody’s immediate circle
We didn’t tell anyone what had happened outside our immediate circle.
a close circle
He cultivated a close circle of musical acquaintances.
a close-knit/intimate circle
His intimate circle was tiny.
a closed circle
He didn’t have much experience of life beyond the closed circle of his family.
a limited circle
His writing was popular with a limited circle of enthusiasts.
have a circle of friends/acquaintances etc
She was beautiful and had a wide circle of admirers.
move/mix in a circle
At Harvard he moved in scientific circles.
be a member of a circle
He was a powerful member of a circle of financiers.
widen your circle
In London she set about widening her circle.
build up/establish a circle
Michael built up a wide circle of customers and friends worldwide.
circle.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to draw a circle around something
circle.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to move in the shape of a circle around something, especially in the air
circle.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The plane circled the airport before landing.
The pigeons circled above the terrace.
